content: The "Prescription Guarantee Act of 1998" ensures access to needed prescription drugs through amendments to the Public Health Service Act. The "Prescription Guarantee Act of 1998" requires group health plans and health insurance issuers to provide information on formulary restrictions and allow exceptions for non-formulary drugs deemed medically beneficial by a physician. The "Prescription Guarantee Act of 1998" mandates group health plans and insurance issuers to disclose formulary restrictions and permit exceptions for medically necessary non-formulary drugs. Participating physicians can prescribe non-formulary drugs, allowing for increased copayments, and coverage must not be denied if the drug is FDA-approved. Nondiscrimination is also required by the Act. The "Prescription Guarantee Act of 1998" mandates nondiscrimination in group health plans and insurance issuers based on prescription drugs. Pharmacists willing to contract with the plan must not be excluded from the provider network. Notice requirements under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 must be followed by group health plans. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new requirements for group health plans. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 add a new section regarding these requirements. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new requirements for group health plans, with amendments adding a new section regarding these requirements. SEC. 713 addresses access to needed prescription drugs. Group health plans offering prescription drug benefits must provide a description of formulary restrictions and allow exceptions for non-formulary drugs deemed medically beneficial by the patient's physician. Group health plans can increase copayments for non-formulary drugs prescribed by a physician. They must cover approved drugs as long as their use is authorized by the drug labeling. Nondiscrimination is required in group health plans and health insurance. Section 515 of the Act prohibits discrimination in group health plans or health insurance coverage based on prescription drug usage. It also mandates that pharmacists willing to contract with the plan cannot be excluded from the provider network. These requirements are considered a material modification in the plan's terms. The provisions of section 2706 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements similar to those for group health plans. Section 2762 is amended to include additional requirements. Effective dates for group market reforms are specified. Effective Dates: The amendments for group market reforms apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 1999. Special rules apply to group health plans under collective bargaining agreements.
